course.subject: BIEN
course.name: Introduction to Biomedical Engineering
course.description: This course is designed as an introductory course in biomedical engineering. The aim of this course is to present some of the basic science and human physiology knowledge used by biomedical engineers and illustrates the first steps in applying this knowledge to solve problems in human medicine. The second goal of this course is to link knowledge of basic science and engineering to fields of specialization and current research. This course also introduces the sub-specialties in biomedical engineering and through real-life examples to emphasize the types of problems biomedical engineers solve.

reviews.author: 高海千歌
reviews.title: One of the BEST PROFESSORS in UST
reviews.comment_content:
Course review (Refer to other post for syllabus' details):
Module 0: Introduction
Just introducing some basic chemistry and biology concepts. This part should be made for students who never study chemistry and biology in high school. Terence said that it won't be covered in exams but I don't know whether it is true.

Module 1: Bioinstrumentation and Bioimaging
This part is more physics since as the title states, it covers concepts in instrumentation and imaging. Especially if you study DSE physics Elective 4 (Medical physics), you will meet some of the concepts again in this module.

Module 2: Biomolecular Engineering and Biomaterials
This part is more biology since it covers more cellular concepts. This year Terence made an unique topic on COVID-19.

You may be worried if you don't have science background. Don't worry, the concepts are very simple and they are easy to follow. If you pay attention to the lecture and the lecture notes, you are  basically fine even though you have zero science background. For the exam, referring to lecture notes is very enough (it is open-book, open-notes and open-Internet) so what actually matters is the searching speed and your awareness.

There are other remarks:
First one is that the class sometimes takes attendance in the form of in-class Canvas quizzes, regardless of your answers. In other words, once you finish the quiz you can get the attendance.

Second one is that there is a group project. For this sem the task is investigating a technology in the current biological engineering industry. You need to write a short report and give an oral presentation. Also, you need to do peer evaluation so don't freeride otherwise you have to take the consequences. You will lose report marks if your peer evaluation is unsatisfactory. Also, an absence on oral presentation will result in the absence of your oral presentation marks. I think the freeride-prevention policy is effective enough so the risk of being free-rided should be less than other project-required course.
reviews.comment_teaching:
I have no complaint on Terence's teaching. It is perfect.

He is a local professor. The pronunciation and pace are both comfortable and easy to follow. Frankly speaking, instead of being professors who always keep a straight face and being serious, he acts and speaks more like your friends, which always be kind and generous. This makes the learning atmosphere very comfortable and narrows the distance between Professors and students. It is very good.

Another good thing is that he is willing to receive feedback from students. Sometimes he asks student to fill a feedback survey, asking whether the teaching speed, content difficulties, etc, are ok. I think it is good that the professor is willing to hear feedback and do self-improvements, instead of always making "self-thinking-good" but actually disastrous education with no improvements.

Not joking, Terence should be a model of university teaching.

Also, remember his name.
Terence(O
Terrence(X
Terance(X
Terrance(X
reviews.comment_grading:
Grading scheme:
1. Assignment 10% (2.5% for each, 4 sets)
2. Participation 10%
3. Group project 20% (5% report + 10% presentation + 5% peer evaluation)
4. Mid-term exam (ONLY module 1) 30%
5. Final exam (ONLY module 2) 30%

My performance:
1. Assignment: Full marks
2. Participation: Unknown. However, I did all in-Canvas quiz so probably full marks?
3. Group project: Also unknown...
4. Mid-term exam: 51/59 (1 question deleted)
5. Final exam: 47/50

Final grade: A-

Although I got A range, I won't say the grade is very good since the situation is similar to other introductory course. As you know UST is a university which is crammed with academic gods. An easy course means that you have to get very very high marks in order to get A range. This course is not an exception although the professor is very kind because he still has to follow the university grading policy (If there are no restrictions, he may probably give everyone an A+ XD). As a result, careless mistakes or free-riders may results in a drop of subgrade. You had better watch out these small problems because you should have no problems on the lecture content while these small problems can take you out.

Nevertheless, a blessing in disguise is that I think Terence should have distributed as much A ranges as he can since he is kind to us. In the lecture he told us that he knew UST is very stressful so he would like to be kind to all of us. Therefore, I still appreciate his grading.
reviews.comment_workload:
I think the workload is light despite having a project.

The assignments are quite simple. Searching the lecture notes is ok and you are able to finish them within 1 hour. Not a big deal.

Although project looks troublesome, actually it doesn't. The written report only requires two pages and the presentation powerpoint only requires 8 pages. They are quite short and don't require many information. If your teammates DON'T FREERIDE and hold meeting regularly, your progress will be fine at all.

However, although workload is light and the content is easy, don't do nothing before the exam. Terence will literally examine every parts of the lecture notes, even things in small corners. Therefore, before exam, you had better go through every lecture notes (If you have sufficient time, better run through lecture videos as well). Make sure that you can roughly remember where the information is. Of course it is not necessary to recite the whole lecture notes (I think no one will try to do that also...). At least you should be able to locate the information so that you can refer to them faster in the exam, but not start reading during the exam.

reviews.author: couch_potato
reviews.title: Down-to-earth professor with interesting content and fascinating lecture atmosphere
reviews.comment_content:
The content mainly revolves around biomedical engineering, originally also including biomechanics, was modified to include bioinstrumentation, bioimaging, biomolecular engineering and biomaterials. Don't fret if you are absolutely new to this: Terence has a Module 0 for absolute beginners in biology and chemistry. I do recommend a foundation in physics though, not pure words like PHYS1001, but actual usage of physics equations and formulas, since the course covers quite a few of those.

No textbooks are required or recommended, though it might help with understanding. Since this is the very first review of the course, here are the details:

Module 0: Introduction
Lecture 1: Course Overview
Lecture 2: What is Biomedical Engineering
Lecture 3 - 4: Basics of Biomolecular and Cellular Principles

Module 1: Bioinstrumentation and Bioimaging
Lecture 5: Overview and Body Temperature
Lecture 6: Bioinstrumentation - Blood Pressure
Lecture 7: Bioinstrumentation - Pulse Oximetry
Lecture 8 - 9: Bioinstrumentation - From Blood Tests to Flow Cytometry
Lecture 10: Bioimaging - Overview, X-ray and CT Scan
Lecture 11: Bioimaging - MRT, PET and Ultrasound
Lecture 12: Bioimaging - Optical and Photoacoustic Imaging

Module 2: Biomolecular Engineering and Biomaterials
Lecture 13: Biomolecular Engineering - Overview
Lecture 14 - 15: Drug Delivery, Tissue Engineering, and Nanobiotechnology
Lecture 16 - 17: Biomolecular Engineering II - Engineering of Immunity
Lecture 18: Biomedical Engineering and Cancer

There are special pre-Mid-term and pre-Final review lectures to help prepare you for the non-cumulative, open-book exams, as well as research sharings in the biomedical or bioengineering field, since BIEN is a new UG Major available for choosing at HKUST as of this review.

Lecture videos are provided so that attendance is not compulsory, but the attendance is still highly recommended since the lecture notes do not include every single detail.
reviews.comment_teaching:
I adore Terence.

Terence is a local professor who studied abroad for a while, so his English is not bad. His lectures aren't the typical professor-shit-talks-and-not-give-a-damn-about-sleeping-students type. Instead, there is a system where he throws a mouse-sized teddy bear and the person who catches it will have to answer his question related to the immediate lecture content. An update was introduced to the system, such that inert students can cover up their faces to avoid questioning. Such interactive style of classes is something that I, having a credit transfer for English Language courses, never quite experienced at the University.

Terence is also very malleable in course arrangement. He understands that his preference on what to teach could be different from what students want, so he regularly asks if we like the syllabus and content. He takes students' advice into account, and improves the course accordingly, which is, frankly, uncommon among professors and lecturers.

Terence is also able to explain concepts clearly, and when he asks students to answer his questions, he would rephrase and repeat the answer for all students' sake. He is also able to remember most if not all of his students' names, which goes to show his passion in teaching and making friends with us.

Terence absolutely deserves an A+ for his teaching.
reviews.comment_grading:
Unfortunately, new courses have a habit of being weird in some regard. In this case, it would be the enrolled students. For some reason, the students enrolled in the class are highly competitive and capable this semester, resulting in a comparatively high mean and small SD.

The grading scheme is as follows:

- Class participation (10%, in-class Canvas)
- Homework (10%, 4 sets)
- Group Project (Total 20%, 5% report, 5% peer evaluation, 10% poster presentation) (If your peer evaluation score is less than 30%, you will lose that 5% report) (If you do not show up for the poster presentation, you will lose that 10% poster presentation)
- Midterm examination (30%)
- Final examination (30%)

The exams are all open book open notes, and non-cumulative.

Class Stats:
HW mean ~ 8.3/10
Group Project mean ~ 16.9/20
Class Participation mean ~ 9.1/10

Midterm:
Mean: 76.23/100
SD: 11.28
Highest: 97/100
Lowest ~ 39/100

Final:
Mean: 76.38/100
SD: 10.96
Highest: 92.5/100
Lowest ~ 42/100

My scores:
Class participation: 9/10
HW1: 2.5/2.5
HW2: 2.25/2.5
HW3&4: 4.25/5
Group Project Poster Presentation: 8.01/10
Group Project's 2-page report: 5/5
Group Project's Peer Evaluation Form: 3.98/5
Midterm: 82/100
Final: 92.5/100

Overall, A-

I really recommend printing all lecture notes, especially the review lecture, and HW + Ans, and bring them to the exam. Helped a lot with my getting highest in class for the final exam.
reviews.comment_workload:
There is not much workload for the exams, since you get to read all the content during the exams anyway. Understanding the content during the lectures is more important.

For the HW, it really isn't much work either, since I finished all 4 HW using cumulatively less than an hour. Refer to lecture notes for answers.

The group project is quite a bit of work though. However, the workload is all planned out throughout the semester, with the weekly group meetings: you can work on the project under supervision from the UG TA.

reviews.author: bsbsbsbs
reviews.comment_content: This is a bit of a bummer given that this course is basically the best course except for its content. The materials of the course are not hard tbh(I actually find it quite easy tbh), but many of my friends who enrolled in the course suffered a bit. The course is named "Introduction to biomedical engineering" and many people expected it to be biology-related. In fact, the content is quite heavily physics-related. About 50% of the course is just telling you the names and functions of BioMed engineering tools, the other 50% is to actually understand the principle behind it, which is mostly physical related. So think twice if you're reaaaallllly unconfident in your physics. You will need to perform simple calculations in exams.
reviews.comment_teaching: Terence is the best instructor in HKUST, period. He explains concepts as clearly as he could, and if you don't understand it you can just stay behind after the class he will NEVER skip those QnAs. So you can ask all you want.
reviews.comment_grading:
Good. Although the mean is high(usually around 80%), the grading is fairly good. Getting a mean would land you a B+.

Homework (10%, 4 sets)
• Group project (Total 20%, 5% report, 5% peer evaluation, 10% oral presentation)
=> ***If your peer evaluation score is less than 30%, you will lose that 5% report*** →(no free-rider ☺)
=> ***If you do not show up for the oral presentation, you will lose that 10% oral presentation***
• Midterm examination (30%)
• Final examination (30%)


Im only half way through my semester so I cant say much about the overall grades and the finals. But I got 54/60 in the midterm(mean: 47.7, highest: 59), I just went through all the lecture notes and made sure I understand the principles. It took me just one day to study before the midterm ngl.
reviews.comment_workload: Light asf. A few quizzes and assignments during class, full credit for participation. Just need to study the materials before the exams and you're good to go. Exams are open book and open internet, so just look up your notes or google it if u encounter something u don't know.

There are 3 modules in this course.
Module 0 is about introduction of biomedical engineering and basic concepts about chemistry like atomic bonding. This module will not be examined.
Module 1 is about bioinstrumentation and bioimaging. It includes blood presure, pulse oximetry, flow cytometry, x-ray, CT scan, etc.
Module 2 is about drug delivery, tissue enginneering, biomolecular engineering etc.

Class participation (10%, in-class Canvas)

reviews.author: Jonti
reviews.title: Great Course!
reviews.comment_content: This introductory course in biomedical engineering was truly insightful. It aimed to equip us, as students, with a solid foundation in basic science and human physiology, which are vital for biomedical engineers. The course effectively demonstrated how this knowledge can be practically applied to solve real-world medical problems. One of the highlights was the emphasis on connecting our understanding of basic science and engineering principles to specialized fields within biomedical engineering and ongoing research. By showcasing real-life examples, the course effectively showcased the diverse range of problems that biomedical engineers tackle. Overall, this course was an excellent introduction to the fascinating world of biomedical engineering, offering valuable insights and inspiring us to explore further in this field.

reviews.author: chickenbro
reviews.title: An easy and managable course, with a great professor
reviews.comment_content:
Briefly teaches about biomedical engineering in a way everyone can understand easily (just the surface stuff, won't go too in-depth since it is just an intro course)

Teaching materials are divided into 3 modules:
- Module 0 (Won't be tested AT ALL) is just the course overview (the syllabus, schedules, etc) and some basic chem/bio information during the add-drop period, not important at all and can just ignore it

- Module 1: Bioinstrumentation and Bioimaging (ONLY TEST IN MIDTERM)
5) Bioinstrumentation - Overview and Body Temperature
6) Bioinstrumentation - Blood Pressure
7) Bioinstrumentation - Pulse Oximetry
8&9) Bioinstrumentation - From Blood Tests to Flow Cytometry (Part I & II)
10) Bioimaging - Overview, X-ray and CT Scan
11) Bioimaging - MRI, PET, and Ultrasound
12) Bioimaging - Optical and Photoacoustic Imaging
if you have studied basic biology in high school / HKDSE physics e4 medical physics then you will meet some of the similar concepts here, though I would say it is also really easy for beginners without prior knowledge.

- Module 2: Biomolecular Engineering, Biomaterials, and Immunity (ONLY TEST IN FINALS)
13) Biomolecular Engineering – Overview
14&15) Drug Delivery, Tissue Engineering, and Nanobiotechnology (Part I & II)
16) Biomolecular Engineering II - Engineering of Immunity
17) COVID-19
18) Biomedical Engineering and Cancer
Materials are sort of *less* than module 1, for me I spent less time doing revision on this. Some topics might be a bit new to some of us year 1s, but most of it is still manageable. Requires some basic understanding of the chapters.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Terence is really enthusiastic, one of the best professors in UST I would say. His teaching atmosphere is great and he will try his best to entertain the whole class, often making jokes in order to not make us feel bored. He has fluent and clear English and it's easy to understand his teaching.

10/10 professor no joke
reviews.comment_grading:
- Participation (10%, in-class Canvas quizzes)
basically you do = full marks so ok

- Homework (10%, 4 sets)
unlimited retries, answers can usually be found in lecture notes and not hard at all

the above two should be full marks for everyone

- Group project (Total 20%, 5% report, 5% peer evaluation, 10% oral presentation)
Marks wouldn't be so bad if you have thrown in some work into it, me got quite good actually

Midterm examination (30%)
Final examination (30%)
both MT and finals are open-book open-notes with 60 MC questions, you can just do revision days before the exam and would still be fine (you will just be mindlessly searching for answers in the lecture notes in the exam hall anyways). Though the difficulty is REALLY LOW so an EXTREMELY HIGH MEAN should be expected

My marks:
Full on attendance and HW (20%)
Project (20%): 18.07/20
MT (30%): 54/60 (mean 49.08, median 50)
Finals (30%): 55/60 (mean 52.85, median 54)
Grade: A-
horrible mean and median for the exams (IT IS SO EASY MAN), you gotta be **extremely careful** and not getting any stupid mistakes or else ur grade will be gone. Though I would say the grading is quite good since I am getting the "average people" results and still managed to get A-range.
I am satisfied with my results though considering I didn't put a lot of expectations when marks come out, but the outcome is A-range anyways so yeah!
reviews.comment_workload:
There are occasional assignments, you get unlimited tries on those so it's easy

The majority of the workload comes from the group project, groups of 4-5, and a UG TA will be assigned to your group. You are required to have a group meeting (f2f or Zoom is both acceptable) once per 2 weeks (at least 4 times, UG TA needs to be there too). Your topic will prob be decided in the first meeting and basically just do some research online and it will be fine for the project. You will do a presentation (not the type in front of the class, half of the groups do the presentation and the other half of the groups + PG TA UG TA will be doing the marks) and a report, both deadline is near the end of the semester.
One thing to note, I highly recommend getting some groupmates that can lead the team forward. Myself doesn't have friends taking the same course so I gets random groupmates (two year 4 students and they lead the group so well!!) and me the year 1 small potato get carried throughout the semester really appreciated!!

reviews.author: svch
reviews.comment_content:
Two modules:
1) Bioinstrumentation & Bioimaging - has a higher focus on physics, a bit more technical
2) Biomolecular Engineering - more biology, more straight-forward, especially if you've studied biology in high school
reviews.comment_teaching: Prof is amazing. He'll go out of his way to ensure students understand and will repeat what he's saying if he feels that the class is a bit lost. Very responsive with emails, usually responds within the hour, and any question will definitely be answered by him. He's definitely my favourite professor I've encountered so far.
reviews.comment_grading:
This is where the course takes a hit.
Grading:
Class participation (through quiz in class) - 10%
Homework - 10%
Group project - 20%
Midterm (only module 1) - 30%
Final (only module 2) - 30%
Now, since the course is easy, the grading is really weird. There are a lot of people who aren't in year 1 who take this course as a GPA boost, like biology majors, who would already know a lot of the content being taught. Alas.
My grades:
Homework - 10/10
Participation - not released, but I wasn't present for one quiz
Midterm - 46/60 (kinda messed it up out of time pressure xd)
Final - 54/60
Group project - 16.3/20
Total percentage (probably) - 85%, which is a B- for this course :/
reviews.comment_workload: The workload is fine. There is a group project but the groups are finalised within the first month of the semester and it's very nicely spread out throughout the semester. If you have a good TA (which we didn't xd) then they'll make sure everyone is actually doing their work. 4 homework sets throughout the semester, but each are very easy, answers can mostly be found in the lecture slides.

reviews.author: CC11112
reviews.comment_content: An introductory course regarding technologies and basics to the field of Bioengineering. You will get a taste in the variety of existing innovations and concepts, such as X-ray, MRI, Blood oximetry etc.
reviews.comment_teaching: Professor Wong is very passionate and friendly, his classes are always enthusiastic and he tries his best to make things easy to comprehend. He provides a lot of help and hints when it comes to preparing for exams!
reviews.comment_grading:
Fair grading:
Participation 10% (In class polling and quizzes, as long as you do them you get full participation)
HW 10%
Group Project 20%
Midterm Exam 30%
Final Exam 30%
Both exams are open book
reviews.comment_workload:
Total of 4 sets of Homework with unlimited attempts
Project included report and oral presentation
Both final and midterms are MCQ questions.

reviews.author: someonekkkkkkkk
reviews.title: ONE OF THE BEST COURSE IN UST
reviews.comment_content: Same as the other reviews.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Explain clearly and willing to answer student's question.
Creating a very good atmosphere in the class, always want students to get involved and actively participate in class.
reviews.comment_grading: Can definitely get A range if putting effort into the course. Above mean will get a B+.
reviews.comment_workload:
4 homework in total. All MC and can simply find answer from the ppt.
There are some random lesson quiz, just for attendance checking.
One group project, with at least 4 meeting with the TA.
Overall, I think the workload is acceptable.

reviews.comment_teaching: He teaches very well and is a very nice professor. He also speaks English fluently and has excellent pronunciation. The professor is very understanding and always tries to make his lectures fun.
reviews.comment_grading:

reviews.comment_workload: There are some in-class quizzes and you just need to attend the lectures. The workload for the group project is acceptable. The written report for the group project only requires 2 pages, so it's not very heavy.

reviews.author: BellaC
reviews.comment_content:
The content is easy to understand, even if you don't studied biology previously, you can still understand quickly.
Module 0: Basic of bimolecular and cellular principles (taught by TA and will not be examined)
Module 1: Bioinstrumentation, Bioimaging
Module 2: Biomolecular engineering, biomaterials, Immunity (including COVID 19, Cancer)
reviews.comment_teaching: Interactive and the professor is fun and nice. There were also a talk where the professor share about his own startup and more about biomedical engineering department.
reviews.comment_grading: Grading is fair, since the contents are easy, the cut off is high
reviews.comment_workload: Low (Homework all MC, Group Presentation and Report, Midterm and Final all MC)

reviews.author: Vibek
reviews.comment_content:
The course was divided into two modules.
I below the exam method would be the same for the semesters to come.
One exam would only have one module being examined
So first sem, module 1, than next sem would be the other module only.
reviews.comment_teaching: Terence has the best teaching style, his lessons are very interactive, he cuts down the hard to understand part into easy to digest smaller parts.
reviews.comment_grading:
The grading for this course is very good.
Getting below the mean is a C+
Getting above by a bit can result in a B.
The difficult part is getting A or above A. The cut off is quite high.
reviews.comment_workload: Very little

reviews.author: ckkkkk
reviews.comment_content:
Module 0: Basic of biomolecular and cellular principles (just DSE biology stuff)
Module 1: Bioinstrumentation
Module 2: Biomolecular engineering
reviews.comment_teaching: Terence is good. He explains the concepts well and his lecture is not boring.
reviews.comment_grading: The grading is good cuz B-range is wide. But if you aim at A-range, it is better to work harder since the content is easy and many students get good results in mid-term and final exam.
reviews.comment_workload:
The workload is light.
There are 4 homework and a group project with presentation.The homework is quite easy. Just MCs including simple calculations. The project is done by 4-5 students and requires students to make a 12-slide power point and give a 8-min presentation. It wouldn't be a problem if your groupmates are responsible.

reviews.comment_content:
Content is a concise and brief look into the many fields of biomedical engineering.

Topics Include:
Bioinstrumentation:
Temperature
Blood Pressure
Pulse Oximetry
Flow Cytometry

Bioimaging:
X-ray
CT Scan
MRI
PET
Ultrasound

Biomolecular Engineering:
Drug Delivery
Tissue Engineering
Nanobiotechnology
Engineering of Immunity

Applications of Biomedical Engineering:
COVID-19
Cancer

Although there seems to be lots of topics, they are not covered in depth, and only simple principles behind these instruments/ a few formulae are tested.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Excellent.

Terence is an excellent instructor. He engages the class well, and provides insightful questions to help us understand the content more. He is very patient and understands the needs of students (such as needing more time to fully digest difficult topics, and understanding common points of confusion and spending more time to explain them).

Lecture videos are provided if you somehow fell asleep (but why would you?)
reviews.comment_grading:
The only pain point of the course.

The grading scheme are as follows:
10% Class Participation (By answering quizzes on Canvas. Note that correct answers are not required.)
10% Homework (Unlimited attempt MC quiz. Questions are based on factual recall only.)
20% Group Project (5% Report, 5% Peer Evaluation, 10% Presentation)
30% Midterm Examination
30% Final Examination

This grading scheme is fine. However, the scores that everyone got in most of these scoring categories are very high.
Midterm (LQ 44, Mean 47.79, UQ 53) out of 60
Final (LQ 48, Mean 51.1, UQ 56) out of 60

Small mistakes may drop your grade rather quickly, so be careful in your midterm and final.
reviews.comment_workload:
Very Low.

For the group project, you are guided by UGTAs, and you are expected to hold regular meetings about your progress. The actual workload, when distributed over 5 or 6 people, is quite low.

For the final and midterm, they are both open book. Be aware that the questions mainly test conceptual understanding, so you should make sure you understand the more difficult slides.

reviews.author: seanlie
reviews.comment_content:
前半係bioinstrumentation + bioimaging
後半係biomolecular engineering， biomaterials（drug delivery） ， immunity，cancer等topic
都係基本野，少少phychembio
reviews.comment_teaching:
Terence so good
1. 流利清晰既教學（無咩口音）
2. 樂於解答問題，只要你問，佢都一定答，試過有次重複三四次同一條問題。即時答唔曬都會落堂繼續答
3. 樂於分享自己經歷，有一堂專門分享自己學習，研究，創業既經歷，俾對BIEN有興趣既同學作參考
4. 最重要梗係講野都幾有趣，唔會死氣沈沈
reviews.comment_grading:
1. Assignment(10%):簡單mc+無限任做，只要你肯，一定滿分
2. Quiz(10%): 有做就有，唔睇對錯
3. Group project(20%): 會有tutor指導，只要唔係太hea，都唔會太低，不過唔好freeride，因為有peer evaluation
4. Mid/Final(30%/30%):因為online，全mc，題目大部分都簡單，所以average都唔低，小心d就好

overall係個簡單既course，所以都唔易好grade
reviews.comment_workload:
Assignment同Quiz完全唔算有野做。

Group project會有幾次meeting，要講野，但present同report都唔需要深度分析，幾個人分其實好少野。不過唔知係唔係因為online，present個日要重複present 3次俾三組人評分（都唔算workload既）

Mid同Final，open everything（除左隔離唔可以有人），基本上大部分都可以search到，有少少係課堂內容。不過其實簡單溫下內容都唔多，同唔深。

可以話workload少到喊

reviews.author: nnaa
reviews.comment_content: The course is well-planned and structured. The whole content is nice and has a good sequence of topics. It is overall a good course.

reviews.comment_grading:
The grading was generous although the mean was quite high throughout the semester, so a small mistake could be annoying. If you’re careful enough, you’ll surely be in the A range.

Project: 25%
3 Homework: 15%
Midterm and finals: 50%
reviews.comment_workload: The workload was acceptable. reviews.comment_teaching: Terence表達能力清晰，又熱衷同學生互動，好有親切感。平時都會一一解答學生嘅各種問題。Midterm之後特登開返個堂同學生講返自己嘅經歷並且討論出路。而且佢仲會以quiz嘅形式去問學生對哩個course嘅意見，以方便作出改善。
reviews.comment_grading:

Quiz(10%): 攞嚟計attendance，有做就滿分

因為大家都好高分，所以哩個course好grade唔係幾易攞。
reviews.comment_workload: 睇落去好多野做，實質上workload仲少過其他 3 cred course。最主要嘅workload都係project度，Midterm同Final open book + open Internet，答案可以直接係lecture notes同網上搵到，唔使好似其他科咁花好大功夫去溫。

reviews.author: yayayayyaya

reviews.comment_grading: It is really easy. The content is quite easy and do past papers! They will really help u a lot. But it is difficult to get A range as the mean is too high.

There is a group project but as long as you find good teammates you'll be fine. The one thing is just the compulsory meet up sessions that may take some more time.

reviews.author: 朱仔

midterm will only cover module 1 , final will only cover module 2

reviews.author: gonpachirou
reviews.title: A great, light introduction to biomedical engineering!
reviews.comment_content:
The content is broad and covers virtually every corner of biomedical engineering, albeit quite shallow since it's a common core course.

Lecture 2 is an introduction.
Lectures 3-4 comprise Module 0 which set the stage for later topics by giving you fundamental biology knowledge.
Lectures 5-12 are all about Module 1 (Bioimaging).
5. Body temperature
6. Blood pressure
7. Pulse oximetry
8. Blood testing
9. Flow cytometry
10. X-Ray and CT
11. MRI, PET, and Ultrasound
12. Optical and Photoacoustic Imaging
Lectures 13-18 cover Module 2 (Biomolecular Engineering)
13. Overview
14. Drug delivery
15. Nanobiotechnology
16. Immunity engineering
17. COVID-19
18. Biomedical Engineering and Cancer

There is also a group project (essay + powerpoint + presentation) worth 20% of the final grade.
This semester, the midterm and final both carried 30% weights. The midterm and final were 70 minutes in duration and consisted of 60 multiple-choice questions. Open-book, open-notes, open-internet (a rarity in UST).

Furthermore, there were also six homework quizzes totaling 10% and six 'participation' quizzes (full marks regardless of what result you get) totaling 10%.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Terence is the best lecturer I've come across during my time here, hands down!
He encourages participation, explains concepts in a way that is easy to understand, and most importantly, answers every single one of our questions.
He also replies to emails at a lightning-fast rate!

For these reasons, I'll give him an A if not an A+.
reviews.comment_grading:
This is the main issue with this course. If you're planning to get B-B+, then this course is for you. Getting an A range will require extra effort in both the project and exams, however, as this course is relatively easy and everybody will be getting high marks.

Data for this semester:
Midterm 30% (Mean 47.8, SD unknown, Hi 59, Lo 17)
Final 30% (Mean 51.0, SD unknown, Hi 60, Lo 19)
Project report 5% (Mean 4.1, Hi 4.8, Lo 3.6)
Project PPT slides 10% (Mean 8.3, Hi 9.4, Lo 6.3)
Participation grade 5% (Mean unknown, depends on your group)
Homework 10% (Mean too lazy to check)
Quizzes 10% (Mean too lazy to check)

The tea (my statistics):
Midterm 59/60
Final 55/60
Project report 4.5/10
Project PPT slides 9/10
Participation grade [unknown]
Homework 10/10

Overall grade = A+
reviews.comment_workload:
This course is meant to be a low-workload course and so going with that statement is the best way to go. Studying is useless beyond some point!

I chose to go overkill and beyond for the final exam, studying 3+ hrs a day starting from 14 days before the final. Lesson learned: DO NOT DO THIS!

Revising lecture slides and notes ~1-2 days before the exam is enough and this is apparent in the fact that I got higher in the midterm than in the final despite not studying at all in the former...

reviews.comment_workload:
Not a lot of work, just around 4 assignments throughout the entire semester. All easy to do if you pay attention in class.

You can choose any topic that relates to the course. This takes up the majority of the workload in the course but if you find non-freeriding teammates, this is nothing compared to other courses.

reviews.comment_workload:
In this online semester, the workload is relatively low.
Only 4-5 lectures have to take attendance in this semester. The Canvas quiz is for record, you don't have to answer all of them correctly.
The homework is all mc. You have unlimited time and attempt.
The group project contains a 10 pages powerpoint and a 2 pages project report about a core technology used by a current biomedical or healthcare company in the industry. Teammates should be the most important in this part.
The midterm and final are open book and all mc. The questions are straight forward and relatively easy. But make sure you understand most of the stuff in the powerpoints.

reviews.comment_content:
This course is designed as an introductory course in biomedical engineering. The aim of this course is to present some of the basic science and human physiology knowledge used by biomedical engineers and illustrates the first steps in applying this knowledge to solve problems in human medicine. The second goal of this course is to link knowledge of basic science and engineering to fields of specialization and current research. This course also introduces the sub-specialties in biomedical engineering and through real-life examples to emphasize the types of problems biomedical engineers solve.

The workload should be light if you have good groupmates.

reviews.author: idontknowww
reviews.comment_content:
Course review (Refer to other post for syllabus' details):
Module 0: Introduction
Just introducing some basic chemistry and biology concepts. This part should be made for students who never study chemistry and biology in high school. Terence said that it won't be covered in exams but I don't know whether it is true.

Module 1: Bioinstrumentation and Bioimaging
This part is more physics since as the title states, it covers concepts in instrumentation and imaging. Especially if you study DSE physics Elective 4 (Medical physics), you will meet some of the concepts again in this module.

Module 2: Biomolecular Engineering and Biomaterials
This part is more biology since it covers more cellular concepts. This year Terence made an unique topic on COVID-19.

You may be worried if you don't have science background. Don't worry, the concepts are very simple and they are easy to follow. If you pay attention to the lecture and the lecture notes, you are  basically fine even though you have zero science background. For the exam, referring to lecture notes is very enough (it is open-book, open-notes and open-Internet) so what actually matters is the searching speed and your awareness.

There are other remarks:
First one is that the class sometimes takes attendance in the form of in-class Canvas quizzes, regardless of your answers. In other words, once you finish the quiz you can get the attendance.

Second one is that there is a group project. For this sem the task is investigating a technology in the current biological engineering industry. You need to write a short report and give an oral presentation. Also, you need to do peer evaluation so don't freeride otherwise you have to take the consequences. You will lose report marks if your peer evaluation is unsatisfactory. Also, an absence on oral presentation will result in the absence of your oral presentation marks. I think the freeride-prevention policy is effective enough so the risk of being free-rided should be less than other project-required course.
reviews.comment_teaching:
I have no complaint on Terence's teaching. It is perfect.

He is a local professor. The pronunciation and pace are both comfortable and easy to follow. Frankly speaking, instead of being professors who always keep a straight face and being serious, he acts and speaks more like your friends, which always be kind and generous. This makes the learning atmosphere very comfortable and narrows the distance between Professors and students. It is very good.

Another good thing is that he is willing to receive feedback from students. Sometimes he asks student to fill a feedback survey, asking whether the teaching speed, content difficulties, etc, are ok. I think it is good that the professor is willing to hear feedback and do self-improvements, instead of always making "self-thinking-good" but actually disastrous education with no improvements.

Not joking, Terence should be a model of university teaching.

Also, remember his name.
Terence(O
Terrence(X
Terance(X
Terrance(X

GRADING
reviews.comment_grading:
Grading scheme:
1. Assignment 10% (2.5% for each, 4 sets)
2. Participation 10%
3. Group project 20% (5% report + 10% presentation + 5% peer evaluation)
4. Mid-term exam (ONLY module 1) 30%
5. Final exam (ONLY module 2) 30%

My performance:
1. Assignment: Full marks
2. Participation: Unknown. However, I did all in-Canvas quiz so probably full marks?
3. Group project: Also unknown...
4. Mid-term exam: 51/59 (1 question deleted)
5. Final exam: 47/50

Final grade: A-

Although I got A range, I won't say the grade is very good since the situation is similar to other introductory course. As you know UST is a university which is crammed with academic gods. An easy course means that you have to get very very high marks in order to get A range. This course is not an exception although the professor is very kind because he still has to follow the university grading policy (If there are no restrictions, he may probably give everyone an A+ XD). As a result, careless mistakes or free-riders may results in a drop of subgrade. You had better watch out these small problems because you should have no problems on the lecture content while these small problems can take you out.
